header.subtitle: Advanced Drug Modality
header.title: PROTAC Technology
header.description: Proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs) represent a paradigm shift in drug development, offering unprecedented control over protein degradation through innovative bifunctional molecules.

content.text: PROTAC (Proteolysis Targeting Chimera) technology harnesses the cell's natural protein disposal system to selectively eliminate disease-causing proteins. Unlike traditional inhibitors that only temporarily block protein function, PROTACs tag target proteins for complete degradation by the proteasome, offering a more durable therapeutic effect.

points.title: Targeted protein degradation
points.description: Selectively eliminates disease-causing proteins with high specificity.

points.title: AI-driven design
points.description: Leverages machine learning for optimal linker and ligand configurations.

points.title: Rapid optimization
points.description: Streamlined workflow for efficient molecule refinement and testing.

points.title: Neurodegenerative diseases
points.description: Eliminating toxic protein aggregates in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s.

points.title: Inflammatory conditions
points.description: Controlling inflammation through targeted cytokine regulation.

content.heading: How PROTACs Work
content.description: PROTACs are bifunctional molecules consisting of three key components that work together to degrade target proteins:

steps.title: Target Protein Binder
steps.description: A ligand that specifically recognizes and binds to the disease-causing protein.

steps.title: Flexible Linker
steps.description: A chemical connector designed to optimize the positioning of the two binding elements.

steps.title: E3 Ligase Recruiter
steps.description: A moiety that engages with the cell's protein degradation machinery.

content.detailedDescription: Once the PROTAC binds both the target protein and the E3 ligase, it forms a ternary complex. This proximity triggers the E3 ligase to ubiquitinate the target protein, marking it for degradation by the proteasome. After degradation, the PROTAC is released intact and can repeat the process with another target protein molecule.

benefits.title: Event-driven vs. Occupancy-driven
benefits.description: Triggers a degradation event rather than simply occupying a binding site, resulting in more complete protein elimination.

benefits.title: Catalytic Mode of Action
benefits.description: A single PROTAC molecule can degrade multiple target proteins, enabling efficacy at lower dosages.

benefits.title: Access to Undruggable Targets
benefits.description: Can target proteins that lack traditional drug-binding pockets, expanding the range of addressable disease targets.

benefits.title: Enhanced Selectivity
benefits.description: The requirement for ternary complex formation adds an additional layer of selectivity, potentially reducing off-target effects.

sections.title: Oncology
sections.description: PROTACs are being developed to target oncogenic proteins previously considered undruggable, including:

items.title: KRAS Mutants
items.description: Targeting previously undruggable KRAS mutations found in pancreatic, colorectal, and lung cancers.

items.title: MYC Amplification
items.description: Degrading the transcription factor MYC, which drives growth in multiple cancer types.

sections.title: Neuroscience
sections.description: PROTAC technology shows promise for neurodegenerative diseases characterized by protein aggregation:

items.title: Tau Protein
items.description: Targeting tau tangles in Alzheimer’s disease and other tauopathies.

items.title: α-Synuclein
items.description: Eliminating pathological α-synuclein in Parkinson’s disease.
